comment.author: 11151551@N08
comment._content:
Silvertown built 03.1873, 5,046 GRT
Built by C. Mitchell & Co., Newcastle, as cable ship Hooper for Hooper Telegraph Works Ltd., London.
Measurements: 338 feet length X 55 feet breadth.
Engines: C2cyl. Iron-hulled, three masted.
1882: Silvertown (India Rubber Gutta Percha & Telegraph Works Co., London).
1916: (Anglo-American Oil Co.). Fitted with cylindrical tanks for carriage of oil.
1920: Used as bunkering vessel at Southampton.
1924: Francumon II (Cie. Venture-Weir SA). Fuel depot ship, Algiers.
1935: Sold to Dutch buyers; resold to Italian shipbreakers.

comment.author: 61132483@N00
comment._content: Presumably names after the "Silvertown" area in Woolwich where the cables were made and loaded.

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
Hi Elsie esq.

The "Silvertown" was originally named the "Hooper" and when it was bought by the India Rubber Gutta Percha and Telegraph Works Company in 1881 it was renamed "Silvertown". The India Rubber Gutta Percha and Telegraph Works Company was based in Silvertown and dominated the area and may have named the vessel in honour of its location.

comment.author: 25946936@N00
comment._content: Silvertown, the home of the India Rubber, Gutta Percha and Telegraph Works Company was named after the company's founder, S.W. Silver. More information on my cable history site
